data.branch#\u003ccode\u003e[branch]\u003c/co: Branch Name: [branch " main"] remote info : remote = origin Merge info : merge = refs/heads/main
data.commit_editmsg#\u003ccode\u003eCOMMIT_ED:
#git_metadata_files A temporary git commit file that holds the commit message of last commit.
If we use git commit command (without the m flag), it will store what we see in our editor while commiting any changes. If it’s not (using git commit -m "commit message"), it will store only the commit message. This file never leaves the local machine & remote doesn’t know this file
data.config#\u003ccode\u003econfig\u003c/code: #git_core_files Text based local/project specific configuration file in the root of .git directory.
data.content-addressed-storagecas#Content-Add:
In traditional Data Storage System files are rely on Hierarchical file system or location based Addresses.
In Content-Addressed Storage or CAS Data is Addressed based on their Contents rather than the location.
Every data is assigned a unique identifier (in this case a SHA-1 Hash __ Basically a 40-character hexadecimal storage) The Hash Value is derived from the contents of the file means any altercation in content changes the hash Value( the unique identifier)
data.core#\u003ccode\u003e[core]\u003c/code\u:
Basic repo settings:
repositoryformatversion = 0 filemode = true bare = false logallrefupdates = true
data.data-integrity--security#Data Integrity: Since the Hash value or unique identifier is derived from the Contents of the data or file, any altercation or changes are easily detected.
data.description#\u003ccode\u003edescription\:
#git_metadata_files Description of the repo.
Note
.git/description is not used by git itself, rather it is used by the web feontends like GitWeb, cgit etc.
By default the repository show this message
Unnamed repository; edit this file 'description' to name the repository. But it can be edited.
data.efficient-retrieval#Efficient Retrieval: No Complex file path needed, just referring to the unique identifier or hash value is enough for data retrieval.
data.file-system-hierarchy-of-git-directory#F: File System Hierarchy of .git/ directory .git COMMIT_EDITMSG config description HEAD hooks *.sample index info exclude logs HEAD refs heads master remotes origin master modules objects 2c info pack refs heads master remote origin master tags
data.git#.git/: The .git/ directory sites in the root of a git repository.
data.head#\u003ccode\u003eHEAD\u003c/code\u00:
The HEAD file indicates to current Branch or commit. It Contains a :
Reference ref:refs/heads/branchname ![[Pasted image 20250413111011.png]]
A direct commit hash, if in a detached HEAD state (Checking out a specific commit) the HEAD file is updated with git switch or git checkout or git branch -M commit.
data.pull#\u003ccode\u003e[pull]\u003c/code\u:
Configuration for pull
rebase = true ff = only
data.remote#\u003ccode\u003e[remote]\u003c/co:
Details about remote repo including:
Remote name: [remote "origin"] URL : url = git@github.com:hrabid/dotfiles.git Fetch Configuration: fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
data.use-case#Use Case: Achieving data backup in CDNs In Git for storing objects.
data.user#\u003ccode\u003e[user]\u003c/code\u:
User specific data like:
name = abid email = hrabid@outlook.com

data:
Markdown is a lightweight markup language that you can use to add formatting elements to plaintext text documents. Created by John Gruber in 2004, Markdown is now one of the world’s most popular markup languages. It is widely used for formatting readme files, writing messages in online discussion forums, and creating rich text using a plain text editor.
This tutorial will cover everything you need to know about Markdown, from basic syntax to advanced features. Let’s dive in!
data.best-practices#Best Practices: Keep It Simple: Use Markdown for its simplicity. Avoid overcomplicating your documents. Use Consistent Formatting: Stick to one style for headings, lists, and other elements. Preview Your Work: Always preview your Markdown to ensure it renders correctly. Use Comments Sparingly: Markdown doesn’t support comments, but some processors allow HTML comments ().
data.blockquotes#Blockquotes:
Blockquotes are created by adding a > before the text.
> This is a blockquote. > > This is another line in the blockquote.
data.bold-and-italic#Bold and Italic: Bold: Wrap text with ** or __. Italic: Wrap text with * or _. **This is bold text** __This is also bold text__ *This is italic text* _This is also italic text_ **_This is bold and italic text_**
data.code#Code:
Inline code: Wrap text with `. Code blocks: Wrap text with ``` or indent with four spaces. This is `inline code`. This is a code block.
This is also a code block.
data.expandable--collapsible-sections#Expanda: Click to expand Hidden content goes here.
data.footnotes#Footnotes:
Add footnotes using [^label] and define them at the bottom of the document.
Here is a footnote reference[^1]. [^1]: This is the footnote.
data.headings#Headings:
Headings are created by adding one or more # symbols before the heading text. The number of # symbols corresponds to the heading level.
# Heading 1 ## Heading 2 ### Heading 3 #### Heading 4 ##### Heading 5 ###### Heading 6
data.highlighting#Highlighting:
Wrap text with == to highlight it.
This is ==highlighted text==. This is a marked text
data.horizontal-rules#Horizontal Rules:
Create a horizontal rule by using three or more -, *, or _ characters.
--- *** ___
data.markdown-editors-and-tools#Markdown Edit:
Here are some popular Markdown editors and tools:
Obsidian: The most widely used & loved markdown editor Visual Studio Code: A powerful code editor with Markdown support. Typora: A minimalistic Markdown editor with live preview. Markdown Here: A browser extension for writing Markdown in emails. Dillinger: An online Markdown editor. Pandoc: A universal document converter that supports Markdown.
data.ordered-lists#Ordered Lists:
Use numbers followed by a period to create ordered lists.
8. First item 9. Second item 10. Subitem 2.1 11. Subitem 2.2 12. Third item
data.paragraphs-and-line-breaks#Paragraphs an:
To create a paragraph, leave a blank line between lines of text. To create a line break, end a line with two or more spaces.
This is a paragraph. This is another paragraph. This is a new line in the same paragraph.
data.strikethrough#Strikethrough:
Wrap text with ~~ to create strikethrough text.
~~This is strikethrough text.~~
data.subscript-and-superscript#Subscript and:
Subscript: Wrap text with ~. Superscript: Wrap text with ^. H~2~O E = mc^2^ HTML subscript & superscript tag also supported:
H2O E = mc2
data.tables#Tables:
Create tables using | and -.
| Column 1 | Column 2 | Column 3 | |----------|----------|----------| | Row 1 | Data 1 | Data 2 | | Row 2 | Data 3 | Data 4 |
data.task-lists#Task Lists:
Create task lists using - [ ] for incomplete tasks and - [x] for completed tasks.
- [x] Task 1 - [ ] Task 2 - [ ] Task 3
data.underline#Underline:
Markdown doesn’t have built-in syntax for underline, but it can be achieved by html or tag.
An underlined text also an underlined text
data.unordered-lists#Unordered Lists:
Use -, *, or + to create unordered lists.
- Item 1 - Item 2 - Subitem 2.1 - Subitem 2.2 * Item 3 + Item 4

data.installation#Installation:
This is the first step.
sudo dnf install hugo

data.borders#Borders: Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge
data.colors#Colors: Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge Badge
data.options#Options:
Name: Description
content: The text of the badge.
link: The link of the badge.
icon:	The icon of the badge.
color:	The color of the badge. gray (default), purple, indigo, blue, green, yellow, amber, orange, red.
class: The class of the badge.
border:	Adds or removes the border (default: true).
